description:
Poecilia mexicana, commonly known as the Mexican Molly or the Shortfin Molly, is a species of freshwater fish belonging to the family Poeciliidae. It is native to southeastern Mexico, particularly in the Gulf of Mexico drainage basin.

The Mexican Molly is a small, live-bearing fish, typically reaching a maximum length of around 7 centimeters (2.8 inches). It has a laterally compressed body with a rounded snout and a small, terminal mouth. The dorsal and anal fins are relatively small, and the caudal fin is slightly rounded. The coloration of the Mexican Molly can vary, but it is generally brownish-gray with dark vertical bars or blotches along the sides.

Poecilia mexicana is an omnivorous species, feeding on a variety of small aquatic organisms, including algae, plant matter, and small invertebrates. It is a popular aquarium fish, known for its adaptability to a range of water conditions and its ability to thrive in community tank settings.

This species is known for its ability to survive in a wide variety of habitats, including freshwater streams, rivers, and even brackish coastal areas. It has also been found in man-made environments, such as irrigation canals and drainage ditches.

The Mexican Molly is an important component of the aquatic ecosystems it inhabits, serving as a food source for larger predatory fish and contributing to the overall biodiversity of the region.
